titleStmt.title: Whereas the commissioners and chief governors of His Majesties revenue (being the persons and officers duly authorized by themselves, substitutes, agents or servants for the receiving, collecting and answering the duty arising by hearths, firing-places, stoves and publick ovens and kilns) have desired that all our due care may be taken, that no certificates be unduly granted by the justices of the peace unto such persons who by the acts for setting the said duty on His Majesty are uncapable thereof ... by the Lord Deputy and Council, Arran.
titleStmt.author: Ireland. Lord Deputy.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 15 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 3 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Whereas the commissioners and chief governors of His Majesties revenue (being the persons and officers duly authorized by themselves, substitutes, agents or servants for the receiving, collecting and answering the duty arising by hearths, firing-places, stoves and publick ovens and kilns) have desired that all our due care may be taken, that no certificates be unduly granted by the justices of the peace unto such persons who by the acts for setting the said duty on His Majesty are uncapable thereof ... by the Lord Deputy and Council, Arran.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: BY THE Lord Deputy AND COUNCIL.
div.p:
WHEREAS the CommiÅ¿sioners and Chief Governors of His MajeÅ¿ties Revenue (being the perÅ¿ons and Officers duly Authorized by themÅ¿elves, SubÅ¿titutes, Agents or Å¿ervants for the Receiving, Collecting and anÅ¿wearing the Duty ariÅ¿ing by Hearthsâª Firing places, Stoves and publick Ovens and Kilns) have deÅ¿ired that all due care may be taken, that no Certificates be unduly granted by the IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, unto Å¿uch perÅ¿ons who by the Acts for Å¿etling the Å¿aid Duty on His MajeÅ¿ty are uncapable thereof; And wheras in the firÅ¿t Act for Å¿etling the Å¿aid Revenue, there is a ProviÅ¿o contained, That in caÅ¿e any two IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, Å¿hall in writing under their hands, yearly certifie their beleif that the HouÅ¿e wherein any perÅ¿on doth inhabit within Å¿uch Country wherein they are IuÅ¿tices of Peace, is not of greater Value than eight Å¿hillings per Annum upon the full improved Rent; and that neither the perÅ¿on Å¿o inhabiting, nor any other uÅ¿ing the Å¿ame MeÅ¿uage hath, uÅ¿eth, or occupieth any Lands, or Tenements of their own, or others of the yearly value of eight Å¿hillings per Annum, nor hath any Lands, Tenements. Goods or Chatles, of the value of four pounds in their own poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿sion, or in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿sion of any other in TruÅ¿t for them, then in Å¿uch caÅ¿e upon Å¿uch Certificate made to the IuÅ¿tices of the Peace of Å¿uch County, at any of their Quarter SeÅ¿sions to be held for the Å¿ame County, & allowed by them, for which Certificate and allowance no Fees Å¿hall be payed, the perÅ¿on on whoÅ¿e behalf Å¿uch Certificate is made, Å¿hall not be returned by the ConÅ¿tables, or
other perÅ¿ons to be aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant to them as aforeÅ¿aid, and the Å¿aid houÅ¿e is thereby for that year diÅ¿charged of, and from all Duties by this Act impoÅ¿ed, any thing thereto contained to the contrary notwithÅ¿tanding. Which Å¿aid laÅ¿t ProviÅ¿o by the additional Act for the better ordering and Collecting the Revenue ariÅ¿ing by Hearthmony is declared Å¿hall be conÅ¿trued, to extend only to Å¿uch Widows as Å¿hall produce Å¿uch certificates as are therein mentioned, and as to all other perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever, the Å¿aid ClauÅ¿e is thereby abÅ¿olutely repealed. And forasmuch as it is Enacted by the Å¿aid Additional Act, that it Å¿hall and may be lawful for the Lord Lieutenant, Lord Deputy, or other chief Governor, or Governors, and Council of this Kingdom, for the time being, from time to time, to appoint Å¿uch perÅ¿ons, as they Å¿hall think fit, to do, execute and perform all, and every the matters and things which by the Å¿aid former Act, or the Å¿aid laÅ¿t Act are to be done, Executed or performed by any IuÅ¿tice of the Peace, or Clerks of the peace of this Kingdom, and from and after Å¿uch appointment all other perÅ¿ons not thereby appointed Å¿hall be and are thereby diÅ¿charged from doing, executeing, and performing any matter or thing relating unto the premiÅ¿es, any thing in the Å¿aid former Act, or the Å¿aid laÅ¿t Act, to the contrary notwithÅ¿tanding. And whereas we have thought fit hereby to nominate, and appoint the Å¿everal perÅ¿ons in and for the Å¿everal Counties herein after mentioned, being all IuÅ¿tices of the peace, that is to Å¿ay, in and for the County of Catherlagh, Sr. Thomas Butler, Baronet, Sr. John Devillier Kt. Henry Barkeley, Marmaduke Taylor, and Wm; Creiehly, EÅ¿qs for the County of Dublin, Sr. Thomas Newcomen, Kt. Sr. Robert Reading, Bar. Sr. Walter Plunket, and Sr. Thomas WorÅ¿ â¢ op, Kts. Dr. Patrick Grattan, Richard ForÅ¿ter, & Robert MouldÅ¿worth, EÅ¿qs for the County of Kildare, Robert Fitzgerald, Henry Brenne, Thomas HewetÅ¿on, Francis Leigh, and Maurice Keating EÅ¿qs for the County of Kilkeny, Richard Coote EÅ¿q Sr. Henry PanÅ¿onby, Bartholomew Fowke, Harvy Mortis, George BiÅ¿hop and Bryan ManÅ¿er, EÅ¿qs for the Kings County Sr. Francis Blundel, and Sr. Laurence ParÅ¿ons Baronets, John Baldwin, Samuel Rowle, and Richard Barry, EÅ¿qs for the County of Longford, Sr. Thomas Newcom â¢ n, Baronet, Sr. John Edgeworth, & Sr. John Parker Kts; Wm; Kenedy, & Nicholas Dowdall, EÅ¿qs for the County of Lowth, Sr. James Graham, Sr. Wm; Tichborne and Sr. Thomas ForteÅ¿cue Kt; and Nehemiah Donnelan EÅ¿q for the County of Meath, Doctor Robert Gorges, James Stopford, Arthur Dillon, Thomas Loftus, George Peppard, Charles Meredith and Stafford Lightburne EÅ¿qs for the Queens County, Walter Warenford; Thomas Piggot of DiÅ¿ert John Weaver, and Peryam Poell, EÅ¿qs for the County of WeÅ¿tmeath, Sr. Henry Peirce Baronet, Wm; Hancocke, George Peyton, James Liegh, Robert Cooke Edward TerrelÃ­ and Edward Barry EÅ¿qs for the County of Wexford, Sr. Nicholas Loftus Kt. Patrick Lambert, ChriÅ¿tian Bor, and Francis Harvy, EÅ¿qs for the Country of Wicklow, Henry Temple, Roger WeÅ¿t, Robert HaÅ¿Å¿e â¢ s, Phillip Packenham, John Stockton and Humphry Bagge â¢ y, EÅ¿qs for the County of Clare, Sr. Samuel Foxen, Benjamin Lucas, Do â¢ agh o Bryan, Samuel Burton Henry Jvers, Symon Purdon, and Henry Leigh EÅ¿qs for the County of Corke Sr. Richard AldÅ¿worth and Sr. Boyle Maynard Kts; John St. Leger, Redmand Bary Richard Hull, Anthony Stoell, Bartholomew Purdon, Richard Travers, Richard TownÅ¿end, John Grove, Richard Beer, Bryan Wade, Wm; Supple and James ManÅ¿er, EÅ¿qs for the County of Kerry, Sr. Thomas Crosby, Baronet Sr. Francis BrewÅ¿ter Kt. Thomas Brown, Richard Chute, Anthony Raymond, Edward Denny, and Frederick Mullin; EÅ¿qs for the County of Lymercik Sr. Wm: King, Sr. George Ingoldsby, and Sr. Samuel Foxen, Kts; Drury Wrey and Richard Maguire, EÅ¿qs for the County of Tipperary Sr. Robert Cole, Solomon Camby, Charles Blunt, Francis Legg, Simon Finch, Nicholas Southcoate, the Mayor of Clonmel for the time being, the Mayor of CaÅ¿hel for the time being Bartholomew Fowks, John HarriÅ¿on, IÅ¿aac Walkden, Thomas Fullwar, Charles Alliock and Oliver Latham EÅ¿qs

OÅ¿born; Wiliam Hibbart and Robert Cooke EÅ¿qs for the County of Gallaway Tho; Caulfeild EÅ¿q Sr. Henry Waddington Sr. George S. George, and Sr, John Parker Kt. Charles Holcroft, John Eyre, Tho. Bar. Owen Vaghan. Robert Miller and Thomas Brent EÅ¿qs for the county of RoÅ¿comon Sr. Robert King Bar. Arthur S. George, Robert Sands and Edmond Donellan EÅ¿qs for the county of Sligo Tho; Griffith, Edward Cooper, Charles Collis Phyllip Ormsby and Roger Smyth EÅ¿qs for the county of Antrym Sr. Robert Colvill, Wm Leisly of ProÅ¿pect, Richard Dobb of CaÅ¿tledobb. EÅ¿qs for the county of Ardmagh Sr: Toby Poin â¢ ze, Sr. George AtkinÅ¿on, Edward RichardÅ¿on and Arthur Bromlow EÅ¿qs for the county of Cavan Samuel Townly, Humphery Parrett & Thomas Newbury EÅ¿qs for the county of Donnegall Sr. Albert Cuningham, Francis Cary, Henry Vaughan, William Dutton Geo. Brooks John Nisbet, John Farwood and Grey Bingley EÅ¿qs for the county of Down Sr George Rawdon Sr. Robert Ward James LeÅ¿ly Wm. Brett Tho. Smith & John Farrar EÅ¿qs for the County of Fermanagh Sr, Gerald Irwyn, Sr. John Hume John Curry James Summerwel James Curry Charles Belfoure & Lancelot Lowther EÅ¿qs for the County of Londonderry John Gage of Moygillegan Geo; Phillips John WiliÅ¿on and Raphel WhiÅ¿tler EÅ¿qs For the County
of Monaghan, Wm. Barton, Nicholas Owens, and Mathew Anktill EÅ¿qs for the County of Tyrone John ChicheÅ¿ter and Henry Mervin EÅ¿qs the ProvoÅ¿t of Dungannon and Strabane for the time being, William Moore and Mathew Combe EÅ¿qs To be the perÅ¿ons for granting of Certificates to poor Widows, according to the true purpoÅ¿e and intent of the Å¿aid laÅ¿t mentioned Act, which We do hereby authorize them or any two or more of them, and no other perÅ¿on, or perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever within the Å¿aid reÅ¿pective Counties to give accordingly, and further for the County of the City of Dublin, We appoint the Mayor, and Recorder of the Å¿aid City for the time being, Sir JoÅ¿hua Allen, and Alderman Enoch Reader, or any two of them, for the County of the City of Kilkenny the Mayor, or Recorder thereof for the time being, for the County of the Town of Drogheda the Mayor, or Recorder of the Town of Drogheda for the time being; for the County of the City of Cork, the Mayor or Recorder of the Å¿aid City for the time being. for the County of the City of Lymrick the Mayor, or Recorder of the Å¿aid City for the time being, for the County of the City of Waterford the Mayor, or Recorder of the Å¿aid City for the time being, for the County of the Town of Galway, the Mayor, or Recorder of the Å¿aid Town for the time being, for the county of the town of Carrickfergus the Mayor or Recorder of the Å¿aid town for the time being, & We require all the aforeÅ¿aid perÅ¿ons to be very circumÅ¿pert & careful in the granting of theÅ¿e Certificates which are to be allowed publickly at the Quarter-SeÅ¿Å¿ions unto none but Å¿uch as are fitly qualified and not unto women who are not Widows, nor to one and the Å¿ame widow for Å¿everal houÅ¿es, nor to widows for the houÅ¿es of their Sons, or their Brothers, or Relations though the Å¿ame were heretofore done; And We do hereby further declare that Francis Earl of Longford, Lemuel Kingdon, William DickinÅ¿on, William Strong, and Robert Bridges, EÅ¿qs and Å¿uch other perÅ¿on and perÅ¿ons as We upon the humble Suit of them, or anly three or more of them Å¿hall from time to time nominate, and appoint are and Å¿hall be the only CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners. Officers and perÅ¿ons whom We have, and Å¿halbe think fit to authorize and appoint to do, execute and perform all and every t â¢â¢ d matters and things other then granting of Å¿uch Certificates which by the Å¿ay â¢ former Act, or the Å¿aid laÅ¿t Act are to be done, executed and performed by a â¢â¢ IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, or clerkes of the Peace of this Kingdom; And We do hereby further declare that all and every the powers in and by the Å¿aid Acts, or either of them given to any IuÅ¿tices of the Peace or Clerks of the Peace, other than Å¿uch as are herein appointed to the purpoÅ¿es aforeÅ¿aid, Å¿hall be, and are hereby Uacated; And We do hereby Å¿trictly charge and command all and every IuÅ¿tice, & IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, Mayors, Sheriffs, Bailyffs, ConÅ¿tables, Headboroug â¢ s Clerkes of the Peace and all other Officers whatÅ¿oever within every county, Borrough, Town, or corporation, Barony, PariÅ¿h. or Place, and all other his MajeÅ¿ties Officers and MiniÅ¿ters. and all other Subjects whatÅ¿oever, that they and every of them Å¿hall from time to time or aiding and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting to the Å¿aid CommisÅ¿ioners, and Cheif Governors of his MajeÅ¿ties Revenue, and to their Collectors, Surveyors, and other Officers which are or Å¿hall be appointed by them, or any three or more of them as aforeÅ¿aid, upon pain of Our diÅ¿pl â¢ aÅ¿ure, and Å¿uch pains and ImpriÅ¿onments as by the Laws and Statutes of this Realm can or may be inflicted upon them for their negligence, or contempt, in that behalf, as they will anÅ¿wear the contrary at their utmoÅ¿t peril. And We do hereby further PubliÅ¿h & Declare that all duties or moneys ariÅ¿ing or growing due or payable to His MaieÅ¿ty by, for or upon Hearths, Firing-places, Å¿toves and publick Ovens and Kilns upon the tenth of this inÅ¿tant January for the year preceding is to be accounted and paid to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and Cheif Governors of ãâã MajeÅ¿ties Revenue afore-named, or to Å¿uch as they Å¿hall authorize thereun â¢â¢ and to no other perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever, of which all perÅ¿ons concerned are to take notice, and to pay the Å¿ame accordingly.

closer.dateline: Given at the Council Chamber in Dublin the 15th day of January 1682.

div.p: Dublin Printed by Benjamin Tooke, and John Crooke, Printers to the Kings MoÅ¿t Excellent MajeÅ¿tie, and are to be Sold by Mary Crook, and Andrew Crook, at His MajeÅ¿ties Printing-HouÅ¿e 1682.
